Introduction
In this chapter we only give brief definitions of the most basic terms in this context. Further terms are defined in the descriptions of the particular operations, attributes, methods and functions. For everything not contained in this manual (theorems, proofs, ...) the reader is referred to the author's thesis .
Definition of rcwa mappings and rcwa groups
rcwa mapping
Let R be an infinite euclidean domain which is not a field and all of whose proper residue class rings are finite. We call a mapping f from R to itself residue class-wise affine, or in short rcwa mapping, if there is a non-zero modulus m in R such that f is given on any residue class r(m) \in R/mR by
n --> ( a_r * n + b_r ) / c_r
                                            n --> ( a_r * n + b_r ) / c_r
n \ \mapsto \ \frac{a_r \cdot n + b_r}{c_r}
for some coefficients a_r, b_r, c_r \in R. We always assume that all fractions are reduced, i.e. that \gcd( a_r, b_r, c_r ) = 1, and that m is minimal w.r.t. the given property.
We set RCWA(R) \ := \ { \{ \ g \in Sym(R) \ | \ g is residue class-wise affine \} }. The set RCWA(R) is closed under multiplication and taking inverses (this can be verified easily), hence forms a subgroup of Sym(R). This subgroup is proper since R has no zero-divisors and only finite residue class rings. rcwa group
We call a subgroup of RCWA(R) a residue class-wise affine group, or in short an rcwa group.
Some further basic definitions
Let f, m, a_r, b_r and c_r be as above. We define the modulus Mod(f) of f by m,
the multiplier Mult(f) of f by the lcm of the coefficients a_r in the numerators, and
the divisor Div(f) of f by the lcm of the coefficients c_r in the denominators.
We define the modulus of an rcwa group G by the lcm of the moduli of its elements in case this is finite, and set it equal to zero otherwise.
We say that an R-rcwa group is tame if and only if its modulus is not equal to zero, and wild otherwise.
Furthermore we say that a bijective R-rcwa mapping f is tame if the cyclic group it generates is tame, and wild otherwise. Analogous definitions apply for non-bijective mappings.
rcwa representation
Let G be a group. We call an homomorphism from G into the whole group RCWA(R) an (R-) rcwa representation of G.
